trial_identification.studytitle: Development of Magnetic Resonance Imaging - Positron Emission Tomography (MRI-PET) Image Biomarkers for Brain Tumour Grading, Delineation and Measuring Early Treatment Response
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Development of Magnetic Resonance Imaging - Positron Emission Tomography (MRI-PET) Image Biomarkers for Brain Tumour Grading, Delineation and Measuring Early Treatment Response

interventions.interventions: 3,4-dihydroxy-6-fluoro-phenylalanine(FDOPA) PET - MRI Brain tumour patients will be observed from diagnosis until 12 months post treatment
interventions.comparator: FDOPA PET scans are not standard practice for brain tumour patients. Standard practice is to use MRI scans to assist with diagnosis and monitor the effect of treatment. This clinical trial will use MRI scans with the addition of FDOPA PET scans. Historical comparisons with data stored on University of Queensland Brain Tumour MRI database (1/5/07 - 1/10/09)

primaryOutcome.outcome: Develop new, more sensitive PET and MRI measures for detecting early treatment response. Historical comparisons with data stored on University of Queensland Brain Tumour MRI database (1/5/07 - 1/10/09)

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Use advanced MRI methods and PET markers and computer analysis to determine tumour response to treatment.

eligibility.exclusivecriteria: Inability to have standard clinical practice MRI or clinical trial FDOPA PET

sponsorship.primarysponsoraddress: The School of Information Technology and Electrical Engineering The University of Queensland St Lucia QLD 4072

fundingsource.fundingaddress: c/o: Prof Stuart Crozier The School of Information Technology and Electrical Engineering The University of Queensland St Lucia QLD 4072

othercollaborator.othercollaboratoraddress: Royal Brisbane and Women's Hospital Butterfield St Herston QLD 4029

ethicsAndSummary.summary: Eligible patients - brain tumour Aim - to develop new, more sensitive Positron Emission Tomography (PET) and Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) measures for detecting early treatment response Treated as per standard practice with the addition of 3 3,4-dihydroxy-6-fluoro-phenylalanine (FDOPA) PET scans.
